paper.title: Measurements of Decay and Snapback in Nb3Sn Accelerator Magnets at Fermilab
paper.abstract: In recent years, Fermilab has been executing an inten-sive R&D program on Nb3Sn accelerator magnets. This program has included dipole and quadrupole models and demonstrators for various programs and projects, including the HL-LHC accelerator upgrade project. A systematic study of the field decay and snapback during the injection portion of a simulated accelerator cycle was executed at the Fermilab Magnet Test Facility. This paper summarizes the recent measurements of the MQXFS1 short quadrupole model and discusses the results of some previously measured Nb3Sn magnets at CERN

paper.title: Design of Magnets for the ALS-U Accumulator Ring
paper.abstract: The Advanced Light Source (ALS) is engaged in an upgrade to replace the existing storage ring with a nine bend achromat (NBA) lattice to achieve an ultra-low emittance beam to generate diffraction radiation. The upgrade (ALS-U), requires a full energy accumulator ring (AR) that will be used for on-axis swap-out injection into the new storage ring. The electron beam from linac is first injected to the booster and then transferred to the accumulator through a Booster-to-Accumulator (BTA) transfer line to replenish the spent beam train before swap-out. The physics design of the AR and BTA has been completed in conjunction with the engineering design of the magnets. This paper documents the magnet design development for the AR and BTA systems.

paper.title: Radio Frequency Power Stations for ESS LINAC Spoke Section
paper.abstract: 26 equivalent 400 kW Radio Frequency Power Station (RFPS) units will be provided by Elettra as part of the Italian in kind contribution to ESS. They will be installed in the LINAC "Spoke Section". Each RFPS will power a single superconducting spoke cavity in pulsed operation at 352.21 MHz. The RFPS is a complete system that operates unmanned, based on a combination of solid state and tetrode amplification's stages. The tender specification, the RFPS main features and requested performances are reported here.

paper.sub_class: T31 Subsystems, Technology and Components, Other
paper.title: First Results of the Analytical Method Used to Reduce Downtime Risk at an Accelerator Facility
paper.abstract: The Los Alamos Neutron Science Center (LANSCE), like many other accelerator facilities, was built decades ago and has been repurposed when new missions were adopted. With an ongoing beam availability expectation of at least 80% delivered to the Experimental Areas (EAs), a balance between cost of spare equipment and budget has always been a challenge. Beam availability data has been meticulously captured and binned over the years to completely characterize the Structures, Systems and Components (SSCs) and other factors that have caused or contributed to accelerator downtime. Over these years, a critical spares list prioritized the spare equipment purchases that were deemed most critical by the management team. In the span of the years 2013 ¿ 2015, significant accelerator upgrades and equipment replacements were performed in a set of activities known as LANSCE-RM. Last year, a new risk-based approach was developed by the management team that included an analytical assessment and a quantitative evaluation of probability and consequence. The resulting risk register (risk-based equipment list) is being used to guide decisions on funding requests and provide justification to mitigate operational risks. A paper by the same authors was published at LINAC 2018 describing this risk-based approach that serves to reformulate the critical spares list. This paper, in the sections that follow, expands on the approach by detailing the specific results of the analyses that led to the first risk register. Additionally, it evaluates the historical beam downtime at LANSCE compared to the current funding allocation choices made to increase the reliability.

paper.title: HL-LHC IT STRING Design and Planning
paper.abstract: In the framework of the HL-LHC Project a full integral test of the HL-LHC equipment from Q1 till D1 including the DFX, called HL-LHC IT STRING is planned in condition as similar as possible to the operational ones. This IT STRING will be assembled on the surface at CERN in the SM18 test facility, using prototypes or first-of-series equipment. Is intended to be both a technical and an integration test. Not only the magnets, but also the entire electric circuit, the cryogenic equipment, the vacuum elements and alignment system will be under test in a configuration as near as possible to the final one. This paper describes the activity status of the IT STRING: design of the test stand, procurement of the main equipment, their installation, the readiness of the facility and of the necessary auxiliary systems and services. The first test program and the associated test planning will be also discussed.

paper.title: The SARAF-LINAC Project 2019 Status
paper.abstract: SNRC and CEA collaborate to the upgrade of the SARAF accelerator to 5 mA CW 40 MeV deuteron and proton beams (Phase 2). CEA is in charge of the design, construction and commissioning of the MEBT line and the superconducting linac (SARAF-LINAC Project). The prototypes of the 176 MHz NC rebuncher, SC cavities, RF coupler and SC solenoid-Package have been tested recently. Meanwhile, the cryomodules technical specifications have been written and called for tender. This paper presents the status of the SARAF-LINAC Project at April 2019.

institute.full_name: Japan Proton Accelerator Research Complex High Energy Accelerator Research Organization Tokai Campus

paper.title: Results of CEA Tests of SARAF Cavities Prototypes
paper.abstract: CEA is committed to delivering a Medium Energy Beam Transfer line and a superconducting linac (SCL) for SARAF accelerator in order to accelerate 5mA beam of either protons to 35 MeV or deuterons to 40 MeV. The SCL consists in 4 cryomodules. The first two cryomodules host 6 & 7 half-wave resonator (HWR) low beta cavities (beta = 0.09) at 176 MHz, and the last two crymodules host 7 HWR medium beta cavities (beta = 0.18). The low beta prototype was qualified, the medium beta is being qualified. The results of the RF tests will be presented in this poster.

abstract_log.comments:
Corrections were made to your paper to fix formating issues. Please verify the changes and approve or provide feedback. If you make modifications, please use the latest uploaded file with the editor's changes as a starting point so the changes are not lost.
Summary changes: - Styles imported and apllied to document. - Abstract styled. - References styled. - Figures captions re-formatted to standard. - Tablescaptions re-formatted to standard. - Sub-section headings had period removed. - Fixed Figure 1 placement to align better in document. - Title re-formatted to standard (ALL CAPS).
The title of Figure 5 has disappeared.
I tried to correct the file, but I do not understand how to do it. Thus I accept it with its bug.

If you will stop by the Editor's office or email me directly the changes you would like, I can try to make them for you. Please email me directly at cuffe@jlab.org.
Thanks.

Moved "C." at the end of 1st line of authors to the 2nd line; Removed period from "Figure 1. shows" in page 1; Removed period from Table 1 caption; Changed the position of Figs 5 & 4; Fig 5 was too big that it covered some text lines and squeezed paragraph in the 2nd column !
Poster Posted, Poster Manned, Poster Satisfactory.
